title: The Iconic Formosa Cafe in West Hollywood Has Closed
text:
Your Favorite Movies Were Filmed at These L.A. Restaurants and Bars 
Its neighbor was the Mary Pickford- and Douglas Fairbanks-owned studio complex, later known as Samuel Goldwyn Studio, then as Warner Hollywood Studios, and finally as Lot Studios. A group called Friends of the Formosa saved the structure from demolition in the early 1990s, though five nearby studio buildings ultimately were razed. The West Hollywood Gateway project next door, including a Target and Best Buy, towers over the Formosa, but its street-clogging traffic doesn't appear to have nourished the eatery with sustainable business. 
Cooper says the building's city status wasn't ever "codified into law," an apparent oversight. Nonetheless it appears that anyone who might take over would be prohibited from modifying the outside of the building, which includes neon signage. 
An interior redux, loathed by history buffs including Cooper, took place in 2014. That same year owner Vincent Jung joined Umami Burger founder Adam Fleischman and a pair from the late Red Medicine, chef Jordan Kahn and manager Noah Ellis, to create a new menu. But the partnership was short-lived . 
Cooper is optimistic about Formosa's future. The location is prime. And although the alcohol license stays with the owner, unless he sells it, it's a prime space for a classic cocktail bar. "It can be brought back," she says.
